The Eighty-Year-Old Child of Changzhou, Zhang Qing, annotates at night:

The deaf excel in vision,
the blind in hearing.
Severing one source of sensory gain,
its use multiplies tenfold.
Returning threefold through day and night,
its use multiplies ten thousandfold.

**[Note:] The opening chapter reiterates the three essentials of stillness and concealment from the previous scripture—all hinging on returning to the source and internal concealment. It also introduces the most subtle and vital principle within the three essentials, serving as the true pivot for attaining sainthood. Hence, it first speaks of severing the ear’s sensory gain—doubling even the clarity of hearing—and severing the eye’s sensory gain—doubling even the acuity of sight. What then of all three roots fully returned, and yet able to press on without respite through night and day? The thieving of essence and slaying of life’s bandits—how could its power be measured?**

The mind arises from things,
dies from things—
its mechanism lies in the eye.

**[Note:] Among the three essentials of ear, eye, and mouth, why is the eye considered first? Because of this: Originally, at the dawn of human life, a single point of primordial spirit coalesced within, unaware and unknowing. Day by day, it grew into awareness, and the primordial spirit transformed into discerning mind. Then, the two eyes ascended, and the mind generated love and aversion, rising and falling with things. Thus, though intention rules the six senses, the eye is truly the vanguard of the five thieves. If this essential is returned to its source, the remaining nine gates and three essentials will return of their own accord.

Hence it is said: *The mind arises from things, dies from things—the mechanism lies in the eye.*

I have heard that in Buddhist scriptures, the six senses and six dusts place the eye first. The *Taoist Canon*’s *Xi-Yi-Wei* ranks vision as paramount. Confucius’ four admonitions begin with *Do not gaze*. Even Emperor Yao’s reverent clarity and King Tang’s sagacious insight, the *Heart Sutra*’s *Omniscience*, the *Dao De Jing*’s *Observing the unobserved*, the Yellow Emperor’s three-month inward gaze, and the *Yin-Fu*’s *Mechanism in the eye*—the sacred sources of the Three Teachings all regard this as the pivotal turning point and the bridge for discerning the Way.**

Heaven’s greatest cruelty breeds its greatest mercy:
Swift thunder and fierce winds
stun all things into motion.
Supreme joy overflows essence,
supreme stillness preserves purity—
Heaven’s utmost selfishness
becomes its utmost public use.

**[Note:] The previous chapter spoke of blind inward observation as the function of returning light and illuminating darkness. This passage reveals the profound mystery of hearing resonance and awakening the mechanism.

Ordinary people, entangled in affairs and clinging to worldly passions, do not recognize their original true awareness. Unless, in a moment of unintended shock—like thunder or lightning—they are briefly freed from their deluded nature, how could their innate purity ever be revealed? Hence it is said: *Heaven’s display of merciless thunder and lightning stuns all things—creeping, flying, moving, or rooted—into sudden awakening.* At such times, those who truly seek the Way naturally receive it directly.

Supreme joy is the joy of Confucius and Yan Hui—the Western Sage’s *dhyanic bliss and lawful rapture, never before attained*. *Overflowing essence* means fully possessed. It speaks of how, in that instant of impact, the entire nature manifests—its boundless embrace permeating the six directions, yet utterly still and untainted. Hence it is said: *Supreme joy overflows essence, supreme stillness preserves purity.*

In my view, a single shock of cosmic void is but the collision of two *qi*—a fleeting occurrence. Yet what of the public or private? Still, no function is more divine than this single strike: Hence, Master Lü’s words—*Brightly illuminated, yet no trace remains; within the thunder’s crash, the root is spontaneously attained*—mirror the Zen school’s striking gongs, shouting, or prodding with staves, all meant to reveal this marvel of the ear’s perfect penetration.

Not only this—even the three bodies of the Buddha do not surpass it. Why? Because *swift thunder and fierce winds stun all things into motion* means hearing the voice and receiving the Way directly, awakening all sentient beings to their Buddha-nature—that is the *Transformation Body*. *Supreme joy overflowing essence* means transcending delusion, body and mind at ease, the nature’s vast embrace pervading the *dharma-realm*—that is the *Reward Body*. *Supreme stillness preserving purity* means profound stillness, the Unmoved One, originally devoid of taking or rejecting, untouched by defilement—that is the *Dharma Body*.

The Buddha’s three bodies are nowhere else so clearly illuminated.**

Then, even the wandering soul may yearn for its lost home, and not stray like clouds or wild geese in flight.

But the intent is to harness *qi*—the scriptures never speak of *qi* within the body, but rather emphasize the mechanism where heaven and humanity converge in perfect harmony. For this physical form is of tangible substance, all belonging to postnatal development and thus cannot be utilized.】

Life is the root of death, and death is the root of life; favor breeds harm, and harm engenders favor. 【The note says: All things that are born must die, hence it is said that "life does not persist in life." The original spirit dies yet is reborn, hence "learn death before death arrives." How so? The innate nature remains unshaken, ever abiding in stillness—what need is there for humans to speak of coming and going, birth and death? Concealment and restraint is the Way of "learning death before death arrives"—the root of life lies in death. If one does not practice concealment, it is called life. Hence, "life does not persist in life," for death is the root of life.

I perceive the patterns of time and things as profound wisdom.

The annotator says: *"People see the purpose of observing heaven and earth as lying in the stars and patterns of the earth, assuming that the study of the* Yīnfú *(*Obverse of the Mysterious*) must be found in celestial omens and terrestrial markings. They go so far as to dissect numbers, trace scriptural threads, and follow textual patterns—yet they fail to grasp that the Dao of seizing divine efficacy and altering fate lies not therein. Thus, those who revere the patterns of heaven and earth as sacred are fools.

As for the profound wisdom of time and things—this is what the earlier text means by 'not divine yet divine.' Time refers to the moment when calamity’s mechanism is set in motion; things refer to the tumult of desires. If one can, at the moment when calamity’s mechanism is set in motion, not only prevent it from reaching an inevitable victory or collapse but also know, cultivate, and even reverse it—then the pattern of time is already clear. If one can, amid the enticing chaos of desires, not only prevent mutual destruction and theft but also turn the mechanism inward, illuminate from within, gather and conceal—then the principle of things is truly profound.

Yet this pattern of time and this principle of things—are they not the very moments, from dawn to dusk, in every step and thought, every touch and encounter, where the closest is not distant and the most ordinary is the pivotal threshold for the transformation of the common and the sage? Fools abandon this for other paths—is this not seeking the far while discarding the near? The ancients said: 'The cauldron and furnace are natural, the medicines are ready-made, the talismans are spontaneously ignited'—these three phrases could only be spoken by the Sage after personal, verified practice.*

---

People deem me foolish and simple, yet I deem the Sage foolish and simple. People expect the Sage to be extraordinary, yet I expect the Sage to be unremarkable. To sink in water or plunge into fire is to court one’s own destruction.

*The annotator says: The Sage appears plain and unadorned, blending with the dust of the world, while the vulgar shine brightly. I alone seem dim. Thus, when people measure the Sage by folly, they underestimate, like water sinking. The universe lies within the hand; all transformations arise from the body. From here, sage efficacy is born, and divine clarity emerges—this is the Dao of natural effortlessness. When the world measures the Sage by the extraordinary, they overestimate, like fire entering—both fail to speak of the Way. To sink in water or plunge into fire is to court one’s own destruction—just as the proverb says, 'Spitting upward at heaven only soils one’s own face.' Hence, I say: Only when the True Person arises does True Knowing arise. How could one know whether my Sage is not the people’s Sage, or the people’s Sage is not my Sage? Who knows whether my 'un-Sage' is the very Sage, or my 'un-divine' is the very divine?"*

The Dao of Nature is still, and thus heaven and earth and all things are born. The Dao of heaven and earth is gradual, and thus yin and yang prevail. As yin and yang push against each other, transformation proceeds in harmony.

*The annotator says: The first two sentences speak of the primordial—what is not born yet gives birth, with emptiness and stillness as the root of heaven and earth’s generation. The latter two speak of the subsequent—what gives birth does not itself arise, with the mechanism of yin and yang’s transformation following heaven and responding to time to flourish.

The Dao of Nature is still—this is the essence of the Primordial Supreme Ultimate. Stillness to its extreme becomes motion; motion to its extreme returns to stillness, and thus heaven and earth’s positions are fixed, giving rise to all things and beings.

How do beings arise? It is because of the gradual Dao of heaven and earth—gradual as moisture permeating dryness, seeping and soaking without cease, merely describing the movement of qi and the interplay of yin and yang. When yin and yang prevail, as yin gradually diminishes by a fraction, yang also gradually wanes by a fraction; as yin gradually prevails by a fraction, yang also gradually diminishes by a fraction. Thus, as they push and surge against each other, transformation proceeds in harmony, and all things and beings fulfill their growth.

This clarifies how the subsequent qi follows time in its nurturing. Yet the *Yì* says, 'To follow heaven’s timing,' knowing that this is the very moment when the *Yīnfú* speaks of the convergence of heaven and human, when time moves and time is consumed, when the sun and moon wax and wane—with no distinction in meaning. Later, the term *fire and timing* is used, showing that the *Yì*’s 'following heaven’s timing' is the origin of fire and timing’s principles.*

Thus, the Sage knows the Dao of Nature cannot be defied and acts accordingly. The Dao of utmost stillness cannot be measured by calendars or mathematical calculations, hence the creation of extraordinary instruments—those that generate all things, the Eight Trigrams, the Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches, the divine mechanisms and hidden arts of yin and yang’s mutual prevalence—clearly manifesting in symbols.

*The annotator says: This continues the earlier discussion of the Sage’s primordial Dao—heaven itself does not defy it, let alone humans. The Sage thus refines a method most precise and appropriate to exhaust the Dao of Nature. Yet the phrase 'acting accordingly' is still not a fixed law; it merely sets the stage for the following passage on 'extraordinary instruments.'

The Sage further states: The Dao of Nature is vast and formless, obscure and traceless—it cannot be sought through sound or calculated by symbols and numbers. Thus, the creation of extraordinary instruments becomes inevitable.

After reviewing ancient and modern commentaries on the *Yīnfú*, I find that whenever the term 'extraordinary instruments' appears, they are either disjointed or fail to capture the text’s intent. Yet the first chapter of the *Yīnfú* itself has already explained it thoroughly. The text says: 'Establish heaven, define humanity,' and again, 'The foundation of all transformations is set.' The characters *establish*, *define*, and *foundation* are the hidden veins of 'extraordinary instruments.' This is also the *Yì*’s 'correcting position and solidifying fate.'

However, the name 'extraordinary instruments' varies across texts: the *Dàodéjīng* calls it the *Mysterious Female*, the *Cāntóng Qì* names it the *Cauldron and Furnace*, and the *Huángtíng* refers to it as the *Dan Field*—names differ, yet their use is the same. All are metaphors for how the Sage steals yin and yang, concealing the workings of creation, necessarily requiring an established foundation and a place of cultivation."

The extraordinary is the name for what is paired;
The vessel is the repository of what is central.
Thus, the **Taiji** is the extraordinary vessel of heaven and earth,
Yet the extraordinary vessel is the **Taiji** of the human body.

This vessel does not stand alongside heaven and earth yet gives birth to them,
Does not consort with the myriad dharmas yet generates the myriad phenomena.
It transcends all living beings, most exalted with no equal—
Hence it is called the *extraordinary vessel*,
Truly the origin of the Dao, the root of qi, the foundation of all transformations,
The progenitor of the *Yīnfú*,
The place where the Sage begins to act and apply his power.

Here, the killing intent is unleashed from this vessel,
Here, the Three Powers are stolen from this vessel,
The Three Treasures return to this vessel,
And the unmanifested manifests itself here.

From this vessel, nurturing yin and yang in accordance yields life for humans and things;
From this vessel, reversing creation transforms one into a Sage or Immortal.
The Five Phases move, and the Eight Trigrams arise;
The Two Principles revolve, and the Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches are arranged.
Uniting and tracing hidden mechanisms, the spirit beckons while ghosts retreat—
Such is the function of the extraordinary vessel.

Know that between heaven and earth, there are originally no myriad things,
Only myriad phenomena;
Originally no myriad phenomena,
Only trigrams and lines;
Originally no trigrams and lines,
Only Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches;
Originally no Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches,
Only the Eight Trigrams;
Originally no Eight Trigrams,
Only the Five Phases;
Originally no Five Phases,
Only the Four Symbols;
Originally no Four Symbols,
Only the Two Principles;
Originally no Two Principles,
Only the **Taiji**.

Obtaining the primal essence of the **Taiji**,
The Eight Trigrams naturally move within,
The Heavenly Stems and Earthly Branches naturally advance and retreat,
And yin and yang naturally ascend and descend.

When the perfecting of the Dao and the completion of its power is achieved,
Yin is exhausted and yang is pure, and the numinous naturally manifests.
Obtain this, and all things are accomplished—
This is the extraordinary vessel!

Once the true nature of the extraordinary vessel is attained,
Then what was previously called the "cosmos within the palm’s extraordinary power"
And the "myriad transformations arising from the body’s marvel"
Now appears in the Three Treasures,
Fills the four limbs,
Permeates the six directions,
Fills heaven and earth—
Clear and distinct, with nothing more manifest than this.
Thus it is said: *"Shining brightly, it advances into the realm of phenomena."*

Alas! The Three Celestial Luminaries shine in vain,
The myriad transformations are already complete—
Yet what does humanity do, that it would willingly abandon itself?
Strive, oh strive!

**Appendix I: *The Vow of the Mystic Gate***
In the year **Gengyin of the Qianlong era** (乾隆丙寅), the **Pastoral Daoist** recorded in the quiet of night: After completing the rites of returning to bury my parents in the **Rensu year** (壬戌), I found myself suddenly detached from the world, as if my bonds had been severed.

Yet in the following year, **Guihai** (癸亥), I returned to **Sichuan**, dwelling in **Chengdu**, traveling between the **Qingyang Palace** and the **Wuhou Temple**. Reflecting on my fortunate circumstances, I grew ever more ashamed of my shallow self-cultivation. Day and night, I remained vigilant, striving for even the slightest progress, to repay the **Four Debts** above.

But since I have taken refuge in the **Pure Void**, there is no way to present my thoughts. Thus, I must lay bare what I have realized, to exhort those who follow.

I declared to the assembly: The **Heavenly Dao is singular**, the **Sage’s intent is undivided**. Though their teachings may differ in form, their conduct is one. Thus, I know that **filial piety and fraternal duty, loyalty and sincerity** are the sovereign principles of the **Three Teachings**, while **rites, justice, modesty, and shame** are the fundamental threads of the **Sages**. Once the foundation is firm, ascension is no difficulty! But if the **Great Root is impaired**, how can one hope to ascend?

As for **heterodox and deceitful doctrines**, they arise from the errors of transmitters. Those who mislead the world and deceive the people do so because their learning is corrupt.

Moreover, the **Five Thousand Words of the *Dao De Jing*** center on **clarity and stillness**; the **Four Hundred Characters of the *Golden Elixir*** seek only to **guard the true**; the *Paramartha Contract* and *Awakening to the True* make no mention of **summoning ghosts or driving spirits**; the *Heart-Seal Scripture* and *Green Flower Record* are not about **burning reeds or refining mercury**. Whether one practices **internal or external alchemy**, all depends on the depth of one’s **virtue and conduct**. Works like the **Saintly Stone’s *Pointer to the Mystic*** and **Master Cui’s *Mirror of Entering the Medicine*** are precise as **gold and jade**; the *Dragon-Tiger Scripture* and *Copper Talisman Iron Scroll* are as certain as **iron and stone**. How tragic!

From ancient times, those who **ascended in their earthly dwellings** were all **men of lofty virtue and abundant power**; those who **concentrated their spirits and harmonized their qi** were all **men of single-minded resolve**.

Thus, the **Three Thousand Eight Hundred** [precepts] stand with fixed measures,
the **Seven Returns and Nine Regressions** [1] are set by their ordained numbers.
The **True One’s** [2] *qi* of Embracing Reality is condensed through the **spirit’s** power—
not merely through swallowing essence and ingesting *qi*,
but when the **first stirrings of Yang** arise,
it is met without contrivance, through **non-doing’s** natural convergence.
Is it achieved by mere rigid sitting in empty void?
Or does one merely tread the earth with certainty—
when the work is done, success follows naturally—
while others chase winds and shadows their whole lives,
yet still fail to find a teacher in this age,
though teachers multiply and the **Way** grows ever more divergent,
virtue thins and minds grow ever more obscured.
Some cling stubbornly to a single corner,
dying without repentance;
others waver like a mouse’s head,
never making progress in life.
Some feign madness to deceive others,
transgressing propriety with reckless abandon,
while others exploit alchemy to ensnare the masses,
betraying principle and deceiving the heart.
No wonder the **Dao** is pursued by countless seekers,
yet **transformation** remains as rare as rabbit’s horns—
even to the point of burying corpses in wastelands,
filling ditches with the dead,
evil winds following in succession,
the world recognizing their folly.
The **lineages of the Immortal Schools** are now nearly extinct.
For those who would heed this warning,
each must **urgently reflect** and turn back without delay.

Step by step, adhere to the **measure** and follow the **rule**;
in all things, uphold **filial piety, fraternity, loyalty, and trustworthiness**,
strive diligently in **ritual propriety, righteousness, modesty, and shame**—
know that the **Great Dao** arises from **principles of order**,
and beyond these principles, there is no **Great Dao**.
Through **broad and skillful means**, accumulate **meritorious deeds**,
so that those who cultivate the **Inner Elixir** may subdue the **Dragon and Tiger** [3]
and command reverence from **spirits and gods**,
while those who focus on the **furnace’s fire** may dissolve **demonic obstructions**
and gather **auspicious connections**.
Seek thus, and attainment will be as certain as holding a **contract of guarantee**;
take this path, and success will be as easy as drawing from a **pouch**.
As for those who still doubt—
let them question the **Three Pure Ones** [4] in their hearts.
If they persist in slander,
may their **spirit** be consigned to the **Fourfold Realm of Retribution**.

**Respectfully inscribed.**

---
**Appendix II: Postscript to the *Yinfu Jing* Stele of Qingyang Palace**

Many have spoken of the *Yinfu Jing* [5].
Some say it was composed by **Broad-Achieving Child** [6] and transmitted to the **Yellow Emperor**;
others claim it dates to the **Spring and Autumn period**;
**Zhongyang Master** [7] asserts it was written by **Daoists of the Warring States**;
still others call it a treatise on **nourishment, governance, or warfare**.
The various commentaries diverge wildly, each inconsistent.

I now resolve this with a single word:
**All are correct, yet all are incorrect.**

How so? The *Yijing* states:
*"The virtuous see it as virtue, the wise see it as wisdom."*
Thus, those withdrawn from the world call it **nourishment**—correct;
those governing call it **statecraft**—also correct;
those of war call it **martial strategy**—equally valid.
But if one insists on which is *truly* correct,
then they are wrong.

Its essence lies in what cannot be confined or fixed—
applied to all things and all principles,
yet never failing to strike the mark.
Thus is it the *Yinfu Jing*.

It is the **original text** of the **Kongtong transmission**,
the **ancestral script** of all **three teachings** and **hundred schools**,
tracing the **origin and completion** of **dark and bright** [8] in heaven and earth,
revealing the **reason for life and death** before and after human existence.
For heaven, earth, and humanity share a single principle—
thus it points to the **Heavenly Way** to illuminate the **Human Way**,
its words concise yet encompassing, its meaning profound yet its practice easy.

In sum:
First, it teaches **discerning mechanisms and observing things**,
then **knowing action and timing**,
and **preventing collapse or defeat**.
Its penetration from beginning to end
rests solely on **natural stillness** as the **practice**,
and **"following Heaven’s vigor"** as the **precept**.
If one can truly **know, prevent, embody, and act** in accordance,
then one may transcend the **born and formed**,
and attain the **land of no sound, no stench**—
forgetting birth and death,
unifying with the **Great Void**.
How could it be limited to mere **nourishment, governance, or warfare**?

The claims of the **Spring and Autumn and Warring States** are baseless;
I retain them without endorsement,
for I say: **All are correct, yet all are incorrect.**

Now, **King Laitong** [9] has inscribed this text on stone at the **Daoist Hall**,
his **unshakable sincerity** not only advancing his own practice
but also inspiring future generations.
Thus, with joy, I write this postscript.

**Written by the Daoist of Changzhou, Zhang Qingye.**

**Appendix Three: A Biographical Sketch of the Self-Tending Daoist**
Composed by Yang Runliu

Zhang Qingye, styled Zǐhái, with the Daoist sobriquet **Self-Tending Daoist**, was born Zhang Zūn. A native of Jiangnan’s Changzhou, he was born in the **Kangxi Fifteenth Year (1676, bǐngchén)**.

In his youth, he was a scholar-official, well-versed in learning and poetry, his calligraphy modeled after **Yán Rúgōng**, a celebrated figure of **East Wu**. He once traveled widely, his spirit unbound by worldly concerns. Upon reaching **Wudang’s Taizi Slope**, he took **yellow-crowned ordination** under Master Yú Tàiyuán.

In **Yongzheng First Year (1723, guǐmǎo)**, at age forty-eight, he ascended the river into Shu, traversing the wonders of **Emei and Qingcheng**. Witnessing the rugged beauty of mountains and waters, observing the shifts of human affairs, he grew ever more convinced of the subtle **presence and absence** of all things. He resided successively at **Línjiāng Temple in Chengdu**, **Xīzì Palace**, content with a single **zither and cot**, his solitude serene.

Earlier, the **Shu provincial governor, Dú**, had repeatedly petitioned for an imperial decree, which was finally granted. His subordinates feared for him, but the Daoist merely adjusted a few characters in the petition, resubmitted it, and the matter was resolved. The governor was astonished and wished him to take office, but he declined, instead accepting the stewardship of **Wu Hou’s Shrine** (as recounted by Master Liú Yùbō).

In **Yongzheng Seventh Year (1729, jǐyǒu)**, at fifty-four, the Daoist moved to reside at **Wu Hou’s Shrine**, severing worldly ties, and immersed himself in **emptiness and stillness**. In his leisure, he studied the *Yīnfú*. With his remaining strength, he cultivated the **imperial mausoleum**, planting pines and cypresses, restoring halls and walls to pristine splendor. The shrine’s side courtyard held a lotus pond, planted by his own hands. A pavilion named **Ōu Chuán** stood to the south, beyond which lay the **Daoist Hall**—formerly called **Cángmì**—and further south, **Zǐyáng Cave**, its scenery profound and secluded. All these transformations were his doing (Note: In **Qinglong Fourth Year (1739, jǐwèi)**, at sixty-four, the Daoist inscribed the **ancestral tomb stele of Qingyang Palace** as **"Reopening Wu Hou’s Shrine, Changzhou Daoist Zhang Qingye."** It is recorded that his administration of Qingyang Palace occurred in **Qinglong Eighth Year (1743)**, when he had only composed the stele, hence the self-inscription).

In **Qinglong Seventh Year (1742, rényǒu)**, at sixty-seven, he replanted cypresses in the rear hall (as per *Chéngdū Língmiào Zhì*). That year, he returned to Jiangnan to bury his parents, his mind and body freed from worldly cares, his spirit unbound. He was then sixty-seven.

The following year (**Qinglong Eighth Year, 1743, guǐhài**), he re-entered Shu. The **Hua yang magistrate, Ān Hóngdé**, and the **Chéngdū magistrate, Xià Shàoxīn**, having restored Qingyang Palace and its lands, honored his **high seclusion**, entrusting its management to him. The Daoist replied: *"Though this is the ancestral hall of the Dao, it is within my duty. Yet I am old and powerless."* The prefect **Wén Gōng** (Note: The old records state the Chéngdū prefect was **Wáng Shíxiáng**) repeatedly urged him, and though he firmly declined, he allowed his disciple **Wāng Yīcuì** to take charge. The Daoist still frequently traveled between **Qingyang Palace and Wu Hou’s Shrine**.

Two years later (**Qinglong Tenth Year, 1745, yǐchǒu**), at seventy, he established **suspended bell and drum platforms** at Qingyang Palace to receive pilgrims from all directions. Daoist assemblies gathered in response, reviving the **pure rules**, and the place became a grand **monastic grove**.

In **Qinglong Eleventh Year (1746, bǐngyín)**, at seventy-one, reflecting on his fortunate circumstances, he lived in constant vigilance. He then composed *Xuánmén Jiébái*, expounding his realizations to guide future generations.

In **Qinglong Sixteenth Year (1751, xīnwèi)**, at seventy-six, **Resident Master Wang Laichong** inscribed the *Yīnfú* on stone, and the Daoist personally calligraphed it, adding his postscript.

In **Qinglong Nineteenth Year (1754, jiǎxū)**, at seventy-nine, he completed *Yīnfú Fāmì*, titling it **"The Eighty-Year-Old Infant"** (Note: At this time, he was actually seventy-nine). **Gǔ Yù** of **Yùshān** wrote its preface.

In **Qinglong Twenty-Fourth Year (1759, jǐmǎo)**, at eighty-four, Qingyang Palace’s halls were renovated, the work completed in stages over eleven years. A stele was erected for its reconstruction, with **Ān Hóngdé** as its inscription.

In **Qinglong Twenty-Eighth Year (1763, guǐwèi)**, the Daoist passed away peacefully at eighty-eight. His **snow-white hair** and **unbounded demeanor** were matched by his **refined speech and calligraphy**. He authored *Tán Dōng Cǎo*. Later, in **Qinglong Thirty-Seventh Year (1772, rénchén)**, **Fàn Yìbīn** of **Shènyáng** obtained a copy of *Fāmì*. As a disciple of **Shàoshān Master**, he recognized that the Daoist’s **secret precepts** aligned with his own tradition. Though the Daoist had already **ascended in body**, leaving no physical remains, Fàn lamented not having met him in person. Thus, he composed *Yīnfú Xuánjiě*, stating in its preface:
*"The Daoist was well-versed in **Southern Palace techniques**, yet his **inner elixir cultivation** led to transcendence. Alas, he departed before I could consult him face-to-face."*

It is further recorded that in **Mínguó Twenty-First Year (1932)**, **Master Liú Jiàobīn**, resident of Qingyang Palace, rebuilt the Daoist’s **tomb stele**, though its text was abbreviated. The *Chéngdū Zhì* also lacks detail.
